results.name: Returning to Solaris
results.description: Stanislaw Lem’s novel Solaris (1961) tells the haunting story of a space research expedition’s encounter with a sentient ocean planet. Here we look at how different artists have responded to, remixed and referenced Solaris over film, television, and videogames.

key_work.title: The Catacombs of Solaris Revisited
key_work.brief_description: This is an enhanced edition of the beloved 2016 art game The Catacombs of Solaris, a perspective maze that plays with your perception of 3D space on a 2D screen.

constellations_primary.name: Returning to Solaris

start.title: Solaris (2003)
start.creator_credit: Steven Soderbergh, James Cameron, Jon Landau, Rae Sanchini, Lightstorm Entertainment and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
start.brief_description: Pyschologist Dr. Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) has been assigned to investigate the mysterious events occurring aboard a space station orbiting the planet Solaris. He discovers that the two surviving members on the station are struggling with their sanity and that the planet itself is a living organism with the power of entering human consciousness and recreating lost loves. Chris Kelvin is haunted by the visitation of his dead wife Khari (Natascha McElhone). This film is a remake of the more philosophical version by Andrei Tarkovsky released in 1972, and is more a personal investigation into the themes of memory and regret rather than spirituality and science. Beautiful production design lends itself to the dreamy and sensual pace. Based on the novel by Stanislaw Lem, this version is written and directed by Steven Soderbergh. Cast includes Jeremy Davies, Viola Davis and Ulrich Tukur.

constellations_other.name: Returning to Solaris
constellations_other.description: Stanislaw Lem’s novel Solaris (1961) tells the haunting story of a space research expedition’s encounter with a sentient ocean planet. Here we look at how different artists have responded to, remixed and referenced Solaris over film, television, and videogames.

end.title: Solaris
end.brief_description:
Solaris is a space combat game for the Atari 2600 published in 1986 by Atari Corporation. It was developed by Doug Neubauer, who owns the copyright and the Solaris trademark. The game is a sequel to Neubauer’s Atari 8-bit family game Star Raiders from 1979. Both games feature an enemy race known as Zylons, but Star Raiders uses a first-person perspective while Solaris is in third-person.

Solaris was at one point going to be based on The Last Starfighter, while the Atari 8-bit version of The Last Starfighter was renamed Star Raiders 2.

constellations_other.name: Returning to Solaris
constellations_other.description: Stanislaw Lem’s novel Solaris (1961) tells the haunting story of a space research expedition’s encounter with a sentient ocean planet. Here we look at how different artists have responded to, remixed and referenced Solaris over film, television, and videogames.

links.description: Stanislaw Lem was critical of both film adaptations for failing to adequately capture the novel’s thematic interest in the limits of human intelligence – so it’s hard to imagine how he would respond to Atari’s Solaris, a space-themed shoot-em-up released in 1986.

end.creator_credit: Katsuhiro Otomo, Koji Morimoto, Tensai Okamura, Eiko Tanaka, Masao Maruyama, Shigeru Watanabe, Bandai Visual, Kodansha, Madhouse, Shochiku, Studio 4°C and Satoshi Kon
end.brief_description: In this anime anthology, a salvage ship crew happens upon a haunted vessel in “Magnetic Rose”; a cold tablet turns a lab worker into a biological weapon in “Stink Bomb”; and an urban populace carries on an endless war with an unseen foe in “Cannon Fodder.”

constellations_other.name: Returning to Solaris
constellations_other.description: Stanislaw Lem’s novel Solaris (1961) tells the haunting story of a space research expedition’s encounter with a sentient ocean planet. Here we look at how different artists have responded to, remixed and referenced Solaris over film, television, and videogames.

links.description: Despite Lem’s disappointment with direct adaptations, the spirit of Solaris (1961) exists in other media. Legendary Anime director Katsuhiro Otomo’s 1995 science fiction animated anthology, Memories, also uses science fiction as a vehicle to explore grief, alienation, and the way the past inhabits the present.

end.creator_credit: Viacheslav Tarasov
end.brief_description: A psychologist is sent to a space station orbiting a planet called Solaris to investigate the death of a doctor and the mental problems of cosmonauts on the station. He soon discovers that the water on the planet brings out repressed memories and obsessions.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

links.description: In The Catacombs of Solaris Revisited (2021), game developer Ian MacLarty captures the disorienting quality of Andrei Tarkovsky’s Solaris (1972). Like the film, the game’s slow visual pacing and sudden perspective shifts contribute to a sense of doubt in what the audience perceives.

links.description: Solaris (1972) created a distinctive visual language that contemporary films continue to draw on. Lars Von Trier’s Melancholia (2011) includes Bruegel’s The Hunters in the Snow, (1565) which features in Tarkosvky’s film, as well as adopting Solaris’ (1972) two-part narrative structure to tell its own story.

links.description: Films like Melancholia (2011) demonstrate the cultural impact of Tarkovsky’s Solaris (1972) on film history, but it’s not the only film adaptation of the novel. In 2002, Steven Soderbergh adapted Lem’s novel for US audiences.

results.name: Quirky, eccentric, charming
results.description: The eponymous character of Malcolm (1986) is a kind and gentle young man obsessed with trams and making gadgets. Such charming and eccentric figures have a long lineage in screen history.

key_work.title: Malcolm
key_work.brief_description: Cascade Films’ Malcolm (1986) follows a shy man (Colin Friels) with a genius for invention. After being sacked from the tram depot for building his own locomotive, he meets Judy (Lindy Davies) and Frank (John Hargreaves), two would-be bank robbers.

start.title: The Outsiders = Bande a part
start.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard, Philippe Dussart, Anouchka Films and Dorsay Films
start.brief_description: There is a girl and two men with a gun. The girl is going out with one man but falls in love with another. They plan a robbery. The robbery goes wrong. One of the men dies. The plot is schematic, based on Dolores Hitchen’s pulp crime novel “Fool’s Gold”, but in this enormously influential modernist film, Godard is less interested in the genre tropes of the thriller narrative than he is in using the grammar of cinema to explore the existential and romantic concerns of his time and place. So, amongst the cheap gun play and B-movie eroticism, there are quotes from Shakespeare and from Le Figaro’s analysis of the massacres in Rwanda; a character’s father is Arthur Rimbaud and Anna Karina’s face becomes the catalyst for some of cinema’s most romantic enthusings on beauty and on love. “Bande A Part” saw a young Godard begin to explore both the philosophical and plastic possibilities of cinema, and to begin his playful experimentation with sound and vision which was to make him the world’s most influential film director. His influence can still be seen in the recurrent use of moments and scenes from “Band A Part” in contemporary film-making: Hal Hartley punkishly re-invented the dance sequence from this movie in his “Simple Men”; Quentin Tarantino named his production company A Band Apart. The crisp black and white cinematography is by Raoul Coutard, the elegant music by Michel Legrand. Alongside Karina, the film stars Sami Frey and Claude Brasseur. Decades may have passed since it was first made, but seeing this movie still feels like drinking from the elixir of youth. In French with English subtitles.

constellations_other.name: Quirky, eccentric, charming

end.title: Uncle Yanco
end.creator_credit: Agnès Varda, Robert Greensfelder and Ciné-Tamaris
end.headline_credit: France and United States of America, 1967
end.brief_description: While in San Francisco for the promotion of her last film in October 1967, Agnès Varda, tipped by her friend Tom Luddy, gets to know a relative she had never heard of before, Jean Varda, nicknamed “Yanco”. This hitherto unknown uncle lives on a boat in Sausalito, is a painter, has adopted a hippie lifestyle and loves life. The meeting is a very happy one.

links.description: Directed by Agnès Varda, another champion of the French New Wave, Uncle Yanco (1976) is a portrait of her long-lost relative Jean Varda. Endearingly called ‘Uncle Yanco’ by the hippies of San Francisco, he is a vibrant artist residing in an ‘aquatic suburb’ that floats on the bay.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

links.description: Both the hippie movement and San Francisco play a role in Forrest Gump (1994), Robert Zemeckis’ highly acclaimed retelling of twentieth century history through the eyes of the low IQ but high-spirited Gump.

end.title: It's Only Money
end.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin, Edith Head, Paul Jones, Paramount and John Fenton Murray
end.brief_description: Lester is a clumsy and awkward TV repair man who is nevertheless gifted technically. In helping out a friend, he is drawn into a mystery involving a missing heir in a rich family. He begins to notice little things, like how much those family portraits look like him. Surely..no..he can’t be…can he ?

end.title: The Colgate Comedy Hour
end.creator_credit: Colgate-Palmolive-Peet and National Broadcasting Company
end.brief_description: The Colgate Comedy Hour is an American comedy-musical variety series that aired live on the NBC network from 1950 to 1955. The show starred many notable comedians and entertainers of the era, including Eddie Cantor, Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis, Fred Allen, Donald O’Connor, Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, Bob Hope, Jimmy Durante, Ray Bolger, Gordon MacRae, Ben Blue, Robert Paige, Tony Curtis, Burt Lancaster, Broadway dancer Wayne Lamb and Spike Jones and His City Slickers.

links.description: Lewis first rose to fame alongside suave straight man Dean Martin on The Colgate Comedy Hour (1950-55), a variety show which introduced the duo to a wide television audience.

results.name: Bear with me...
results.description: From lovable anthropomorphic bears to hyperreal grizzlies, explore connections between cartoon and CGI bears across screen culture.

key_work.title: Humphrey B Bear
key_work.credit_line:
Plush toy (1976) and Hand puppet (1977), Classic Toys Pty Ltd. ACMI Collection. Donated by Daniel Clem, 2022

The Adventures of Humphrey Bear (1974), Gordon A. Rule, published by Rigby Ltd

Vinyl LP (1972), Jigsaw puzzle (1983), Mug & bowl (c.1983), Puzzle clock (1983), Bath book (1989), Southern Television Corp. Pty Ltd

Black and white publicity stills (1980s, ACMI Collection), Plaster moulding set (1991), Humphrey in the Snow VHS (1994, ACMI Collection, Banksia Productions
key_work.brief_description: The fun-loving Humphrey B Bear first bounded onto Australian TV in 1965 and has been bringing joy to children and adults ever since. Humphrey was the star of the Here’s Humphrey show, one of the world’s longest-running kids’ TV shows with around 3,000 episodes. Humphrey’s popularity is evident in all this merchandise and memorabilia. From plush toys and vinyl records to bath books and plaster sets, Humphrey has inspired children across decades to play, learn and create at home.

end.title: Here's Humphrey
end.brief_description: Here’s Humphrey is an Australian children’s television series first aired on Monday 24 May 1965 on the Nine Network. It featured a character known as Humphrey B. Bear. In the early days Humphrey was known as Bear Bear and was named Humphrey B. Bear as the result of an on-air competition. Here’s Humphrey has become one of the most successful programs for pre-schoolers in Australia.

start.title: Hooked Bear
start.creator_credit: Jack Hannah, Walt Disney, Walt Disney Productions, Al Bertino and David Detiege
start.brief_description: Humphrey the bear isn’t having much luck with his fishing; every time he catches some nice fish, he gets distracted and drops them. So he goes after the catches of the local anglers instead. But ranger Woodlore frowns on this, insisting the bear fish like one.

constellations_other.name: Bear with me...

end.title: Banjo-Kazooie
end.brief_description: In this 3D platformer, the heroic but naive bear Banjo enlists his cowardly bird buddy Kazooie to help rescue his younger sister from a vain, beauty-stealing witch. The player is tasked with exploring the witch’s lair and the nine large, open levels within it, looking for tasks and challenges to complete. Along the way they meet a variety of characters who teach them new moves and transform them into different animals. Modeled after Super Mario 64, Banjo-Kazooie is distinguished by its cheeky and sarcastic sense of humor and by a large, varied, and novel moveset.

links.description: Like Humphrey the Bear, Banjo the bear from the single-player videogame Banjo-Kazooie (1998) makes vocal sounds to convey dialogue and emotions instead of speaking. Banjo and other characters’ voices are subtitled to make the videogame available in multiple languages.

end.title: Kung Fu Panda 2
end.creator_credit: Jennifer Yuh Nelson, Glenn Berger, Jonathan Aibel, Clare Knight, Maryann Brandon, Melissa Cobb, DreamWorks Animation and Raymond Zibach
end.brief_description: Po is now living his dream as The Dragon Warrior, protecting the Valley of Peace alongside his friends and fellow kung fu masters, The Furious Five - Tigress, Crane, Mantis, Viper and Monkey. But Po’s new life of awesomeness is threatened by the emergence of a formidable villain, who plans to use a secret, unstoppable weapon to conquer China and destroy kung fu. It is up to Po and The Furious Five to journey across China to face this threat and vanquish it. But how can Po stop a weapon that can stop kung fu? He must look to his past and uncover the secrets of his mysterious origins; only then will he be able to unlock the strength he needs to succeed.

links.description: Banjo is one part of the bear-bird fighting duo Banjo-Kazooie, who rely on combined attack moves to save Banjo’s sister Tooty. Similarly, Po the Panda Bear fights alongside the Furious Five to protect the Valley of Peace in Kung Fu Panda 2 (2011).

But Po’s new life of awesomeness is threatened by the emergence of a formidable villain, who plans to use a secret, unstoppable weapon to conquer China and destroy kung fu. It is up to Po and The Furious Five to journey across China to face this threat and vanquish it. But how can Po stop a weapon that can stop kung fu? He must look to his past and uncover the secrets of his mysterious origins; only then will he be able to unlock the strength he needs to succeed.

start.brief_description: Here’s Humphrey is an Australian children’s television series first aired on Monday 24 May 1965 on the Nine Network. It featured a character known as Humphrey B. Bear. Here’s Humphrey has become one of the most successful programs for pre-schoolers in Australia.

key_work.title: Upside-down heads
key_work.brief_description: Upside down heads, which date back to around the 1700s, were one of the most popular Victorian era optical illusions, featuring on playing cards, match boxes, puzzles and in newspapers, where peacocks morphed into bearded men and royalty turned into skeletons.

end.title: Full metal jacket
end.creator_credit: Stanley Kubrick and Warner Bros Pictures
end.brief_description: Stanley Kubrick’s disturbing and darkly funny Vietnam war drama about the dehumanizing process involved in turning young men into trained killers is divided into two distinct acts. Based on Gustav Hasford’s “The Short-Timers”, the first part focuses on the slow descent into madness of a young recruit in basic training, Private Gomer Pyle (Vincent D’Onofrio). He undergoes a process of systematic torture, verbal abuse and cruel disciplinary measures administered by a sadistic drill Sergeant (Lee Emery). The second part shows the bastardization process in action as it follows Private Joker (Mathew Modine) as he navigates himself around the madness and senselessness of the Vietnam war. This isn’t the first time Kubrick has dealt with the inhumanities of war, having tackled similar themes in the brilliant ‘Paths of Glory’. With ‘Full Metal Jacket’ however, he achieves in presenting an absurd and chilling vision of hell on earth. Cast also includes Adam Baldwin, Arliss Howard, Dorian Harewood and Kevyn Major Hasford. Original music by Abigail Mead (Kubrick’s daughter Vivian Kubrick).

key_work.title: Epiphytes
key_work.credit_line:
2022

Tully Arnot, b. 1984, Gadigal land

Lives and works, Hong Kong

Free-roam virtual reality environment, spatial sound, scent, carpet, reading room

Created in collaboration with Dr Josh Harle of Tactical Space Lab
key_work.material_description: Oculus Quest 2 virtual reality headset, APK files, reading material, furniture and mixed media
key_work.brief_description: Epiphytes is a VR work by Australian artist Tully Arnot promoting a plant-based perspective. Reflecting Arnot’s interest in how emergent technologies help form human understanding of the world, the visually diffuse nature of the work is deliberate. In Epiphytes, the primacy of sight is de-escalated, and sound and scent become key - used by Arnot to manipulate our bodily responses within the virtual space. “Epiphytes” encourages audiences to adjust the way we understand our own senses of perception by drawing our attention to alternative forms of plant communication and consciousness.

end.brief_description: A young British girl born and reared in India loses her neglectful parents in an earthquake. She is returned to England to live at her uncle’s castle. results.name: Suburban scenes
results.description: Lisa McCune is best known for her role as Constable Maggie Doyle in the television series Blue Heelers (1994–2006). In addition to showing the day-to-day lives of police in a small Victorian town, the series explores the various dynamics of suburbia—a theme present throughout the whole of screen media.

key_work.title: Lisa McCune's TV Week Logie awards
key_work.brief_description: These Logies recognise Lisa McCune’s work as Constable Margret Doyle on the series Blue Heelers (1994-2006). Netting her four golden Logies and ten overall, the character was praised as one of the strongest parts of the show. The episode in which Margret is killed, One More Day, is considered one of the best of the series and a landmark moment in Australian television. The part propelling her to stardom, McCune later enjoyed success in Sea Patrol (2007–2011), another series by Blue Heeler co-creator Hal McElroy, in addition to numerous other roles in various TV shows and films.

Trapped in his home due to a broken leg, L.B. Jefferies watches the lives of his neighbours play out through his apartment window, eventually convincing himself that one of them has committed a murder.

start.title: Lisa McCune's TV Week Logie awards
start.brief_description: These Logies recognise Lisa McCune’s work as Constable Margret Doyle on the series Blue Heelers (1994-2006). Netting her four golden Logies and ten overall, the character was praised as one of the strongest parts of the show. The episode in which Margret is killed, One More Day, is considered one of the best of the series and a landmark moment in Australian television. The part propelling her to stardom, McCune later enjoyed success in Sea Patrol (2007–2011), another series by Blue Heeler co-creator Hal McElroy, in addition to numerous other roles in various TV shows and films.

results.name: Indigenous futurisms
results.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.

key_work.title: More Than Just a Game
key_work.material_description: Videogame, arcade machine handcrafted from reclaimed Australian blackwood, LED lettering, custom flooring
key_work.brief_description:
“Just like in the arcade games of the past, the government initiatives that exist are currently about us, without us. I want us to be seen, to have a say that enables us to take back control.”

Jarra Karalinar Steel conjures the nostalgic excitement of 1990s videogame arcades in More Than Just a Game. At its centre is The Adventures of Dolly, a playable game made with Wiradjuri and Ngiyampaa illustrator Charlotte Allingham. Take the controls and take Dolly on a journey through an alternate reality or not-so-distant future of Melbourne’s CBD, featuring iconic trams and Swanston Street.Growing up, videogame protagonists weren’t relatable to Jarra.

This work remedies that, giving First Peoples a chance to see ourselves imagined in a videogame – made for us, by us. Through The Adventures of Dolly, custom possum and wallaby spirit flooring and the hand-carved arcade cabinet, Jarra reclaims a place that hasn’t reflected our experiences. She brings Indigenous stories into gaming, inspiring the next generation and giving us power to determine our own futures.

constellations_primary.name: Indigenous futurisms
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.

links.description: Jarra Karalinar Steel works with Melbourne-based videogame developers Guck, who are creating the first Aboriginal-led mobile game. Future Folklore is set in a futuristic fantasy environment inspired by native flora and fauna and First Nations culture.

start.title: Never Alone
start.brief_description:
Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is an atmospheric puzzle platformer and the first game to be developed in collaboration with the Iñupiat, an Alaska Native people, drawn from a traditional story that has been shared across the generations. Nearly 40 Alaska Native elders, storytellers and community members contributed to the development of the game.

It features two characters, and it can be played in single-player mode or play cooperatively with a friend as you trek through frozen tundra, leap across treacherous ice floes, swim through underwater caverns and face enemies both strange and familiar.

You’ll explore awe-inspiring environments, perform heroic deeds and meet legendary characters from Iñupiaq stories — all narrated by a master storyteller in the spoken Iñupiaq language.

end.title: Night cries: a rural tragedy
end.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt and Penny McDonald
end.brief_description: In Tracey Moffatt’s re-imaging of the pivotal Australian film “Jedda”, a middle-aged Aboriginal woman returns to her outback home to nurse her dying white mother. Filmed against lushly coloured sets that recall the technicolour glories of the past, and utilising a harsh discordant soundscape, “Night Cries” occupies the landscape of dreams and the classic mythic terrain of familial violence and betrayal. This short film does more than simply reconfigure and re-imagine past narratives. It inaugurated a clear and permament break with previous moving image representations of the “outback”: no longer the pretence that it is a place outside language and history.

results.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
results.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

key_work.title: Birth of Dawn
key_work.material_description: single-channel video, colour, sound and scent
key_work.brief_description:
Hannah Brontë’s Birth of Dawn explores the cycle of life, birth, death and rebirth through the lens of the femme body. The sun, reimagined as a pregnant belly, symbolises the moment before new life enters the world. The work invites us to consider the Earth as a living, breathing body and questions how we move across it.

Set on a planet yet to experience its first dawn, this dreamscape merges ancient and futuristic landscapes, free from man-made objects. The inhabitants communicate through movement and telepathic frequencies projected through the soundscape. Having evolved beyond language, they experience every emotion that comes with growth – pain and pleasure ripple across each frame.

Birth of Dawn transports you into the present moment through bass-heavy waves, where past and future merge into one continuous cycle. There is no beginning or end here – only the infinite potential of new life and transformation.

There is nothing more science fiction than nature itself.

Created on the unceded lands of Yugambeh, Arakwal and Bundjalung Country

end.title: DIGGERMODE
end.creator_credit: Joel Sherwood Spring
end.brief_description:
“Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction and storage, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind-the-servers look into how memory works within platform capitalism.”

“DIGGERMODE” questions the social and environmental ethics of technology in constructing, storing and sharing our images, whether in surveillance databases, museum archives or online. With artificial intelligence (AI), Joel Sherwood Spring has created landscapes in the style of acclaimed Arrernte artist Albert Namatjira being torn apart by mining machinery, and has trained another AI to answer questions like “Who’s your Mob?” Presumably, anyone could do this – but should anyone be able to appropriate Indigenous art from the internet? How do we protect our knowledges in digital spaces? Can sand used to make silicon microchips contain memories of Country?

Joel’s work confronts the viewer with uncomfortable and overlooked aspects of our hyper-networked age, grounding the possibilities of ‘the cloud’ and AI in the broader context of ongoing colonisation. The work considers the environmental damage caused by new technology and data storage, and how it is Indigenous peoples whose lands and ways of being are profoundly impacted by capitalism’s extractive processes.

start.title: Scripture for a smoke screen: Episode 1 – dolphin house
start.creator_credit: Amrita Hepi, Luke Smith and Zoe Theodore
start.brief_description:
“I’m interested in exploring the gulf between lived experience and its representation, and how identity and ideas around intelligence are constantly being shaped, amplified or flattened through the experience of surveillance and misidentification.”

In the 1960s, scientists tried to talk to dolphins. The experiment was backed by NASA, who were investigating ways to communicate with extra-terrestrial life. One intelligence test attempted to determine self-awareness by seeing if the dolphins recognised themselves in a mirror.

Amrita Hepi draws on that trial in “Scripture for a smokescreen: Episode 1 – dolphin house”, seemingly seducing her own image. She dances with an inflatable dolphin, attempting to communicate with it through voice and movement, paralleling the intimacy between one of the researchers, Margaret Lovatt, and a male dolphin during the experiment.

Not only does Amrita lampoon the absurdity of teaching marine mammals English, she uses the study to expose the way Western knowledge systems – language, ethics and science – are imposed on people and cultures through colonisation. Through choreographed dance and moving image, Amrita explores what happens when we’re constantly under surveillance, and when assumptions about us are presented to the world through someone else’s viewpoint.

Amrita Hepi is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery

end.title: Hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy. - Volume 1.
end.creator_credit: Alan J.W. Bell and British Broadcasting Corporation
end.brief_description: This is the story of the Hitchhiker’s guide to the galaxy. Perhaps the most remarkable - certainly the most successful - book ever to come out of the great publishing corporations of Ursa Minor. The story of Arthur Dent, a seemingly normal Englishman whose ordinary life suddenly takes a startling turn one Thursday. A Thursday which becomes steadily more extraordinary when his buddy Ford Prefect imparts the terrible, hideous news: He’s not from Earth and the Earth’s going to be demolished in 12 minutes to make way for a new hyperspace bypass! This program brings to life once more the magic of the cult TV series.

end.title: Avert
end.creator_credit: Steven Rhall
end.credit_line: Steven Rhall is represented by MARS Gallery
end.material_description: Particle board, krypton-filled glass, light sensitive paint, video cameras, coaxial cable, electric motor, LCD monitors, architectural intervention, various supports
end.brief_description:
“Photography’s historical association with the colonial project has positioned the gaze within the coloniality of power – a system which compartmentalises First Nations art and cultural practice, bound by an essentialist lens. Avert rejects this position.”

First Peoples are constantly captured by the white gaze. Historically, the camera has been weaponised through anthropological photography and surveillance. There is also a history of retaliation by First Peoples subverting this gaze in contemporary art and screen culture. Avert joins the legacy of resisting this pervasive observation, turning every viewer – every watcher – into the watched. Steven Rhall does this by refusing the gaze, obscuring the view of the work and aiming surveillance cameras at the viewer.

The frame of the gallery itself is also called into question. What role do institutions like museums play in promoting narratives and practices that have been used to oppress us? How have Western notions of artmaking put limits on Indigenous expression? By forcing you to view through a peephole, Steven challenges the very walls in which art exists and the role of museums in telling our stories.

constellations_primary.name: Flipping the gaze (Placeholder)
constellations_primary.description: Steven Rhall's Avert considers how the white gaze has been trained on First Peoples and flips the surveillance by turning the camera on the viewer.

links.description: Non-human creatures save the day once again in Indigenous-made videogame Thunderbird Strike. The mythical creature Thunderbird destroys infrastructure and equipment that is extracting oil from native lands, and revives native animals who have been killed.

start.title: Hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy. - Volume 1.
start.creator_credit: Alan J.W. Bell and British Broadcasting Corporation
start.brief_description: This is the story of the Hitchhiker’s guide to the galaxy. Perhaps the most remarkable - certainly the most successful - book ever to come out of the great publishing corporations of Ursa Minor. The story of Arthur Dent, a seemingly normal Englishman whose ordinary life suddenly takes a startling turn one Thursday. A Thursday which becomes steadily more extraordinary when his buddy Ford Prefect imparts the terrible, hideous news: He’s not from Earth and the Earth’s going to be demolished in 12 minutes to make way for a new hyperspace bypass! This program brings to life once more the magic of the cult TV series.

end.title: Jupiter and Mars
end.creator_credit: Tigertron
end.brief_description: Two dolphins are on a quest to save the planet after catastrophic sea-level rise due to climate change. Guided by a unique ‘echo-location’ game mechanic based on the sonar abilities of dolphins, players navigate sunken landmarks and vast oceans.

links.description: The dolphins in The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy tried to save the planet, but humans misinterpreted their warnings. In Jupiter and Mars, two dolphins are on a quest to save the planet from sea-levels rising due to climate change.

results.name: Reclaiming the archive
results.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

key_work.title: Rodeo Baby!
key_work.brief_description:
“The artwork is centred upon the belief that it is our own bodies that are the truest archive of our experience and that any documentation is only ever an approximation of the person doing the gazing – not the gazed.”

While trawling archival video material, Jazz Money discovered an overwhelming amount of footage of First Peoples in rodeos. There was the joy of seeing Blak faces, but an unease in knowing non-Indigenous voyeurs likely captured the footage. In the vast network of archives in this country’s institutions, photos and videos of First Peoples are filed away, with the people who have been recorded – often unknowingly – and their descendants unaware the recordings exist.

Jazz reclaims these images, combining them with stills from film and TV, including “The Phantom Stockman” (1953), “Radiance” (1998) and” The Drover’s Wife” (2021), in this large-scale photographic essay. It celebrates First Peoples representation and the Aboriginal scholars who critique this colonial hoarding, giving new meaning to images that have been dislocated by archival practices. Jazz asks, “If these archival collections are the rodeo, who is playing cowboy with our images?”

constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

links.description: Jazz Money’s Rodeo Baby! reclaims images of First Peoples from screen archives. One such image is from Rachel Perkins’ film Radiance, which depicts a scene when the three female leads burn down their family home.

start.brief_description: An American brother and sister move to Australia to manage a cattle station, but the brother’s racist attitude causes problems. After hearing a message by evangelist Billy Graham on the radio though, he has a change of heart and learns to accept the Aboriginal people.

links.description: Yorta Yorta man Jimmy Little wrote and performed the song “Shadow of the Boomerang” for the film of the same name. In the film, Jimmy’s performance of the song was a catalyst in changing the heart of the racist protagonist.

results.name: The radical power of the glitch
results.description: Brian Eno said, “Whatever you now find weird, ugly, uncomfortable and nasty about a new medium will surely become its signature.” Videogame glitches can seem annoying or obstructive – but for the artists in Out of Bounds, they offer radical creative potential.

key_work.title: Out of Bounds
key_work.brief_description:
Out of Bounds follows a group of Melbourne-based artists (Goldie Bartlett, Andrew Brophy, Ian MacLarty and Kalonica Quigley) known as The Grannies as they break ‘out of bounds’ in Rockstar Games’ hit action-adventure videogame Red Dead Redemption 2, travelling beyond the authored limits of the game’s virtual world and into the increasingly broken and abstract space beyond. Rather than being driven by the desire to dominate or ‘win’, their adventures are driven by creative curiosity, presenting play as not just an end in itself, but as a form of artistic practice.

Through a multichannel video artwork titled The Grannies (dir. Marie Foulston), which is narrated by The Grannies themselves, plus an original artistic videogame and stunning stills, Out of Bounds: Exploring the Limits of Videogames asks what exists beyond the border of the digital worlds we inhabit.

The Grannies is accompanied by an original experimental videogame by Ian MacLarty called Red Desert Render, which seeks to recreate the feeling of curiosity and community that The Grannies themselves felt during their adventures out of bounds, and previously unseen images from the artists’ other adventures beyond the map.

Out of Bounds offers a rare glimpse into the cracks of the apparent seamlessness of the digital world through an artist’s eyes.

We live in a digital world. Bouncing between email, apps, video conferences,
social media and videogames, our lives are channeled through highly curated
virtual realms, each designed towards set goals and particular tasks.
But what happens if we don’t play by the rules?
Using screen-captured footage and stills from Red Dead Redemption 2,
Out of Bounds follows the adventures of a group of Melbourne-based artists
as they break ‘out of bounds’ in Rockstar Games’ hit action-adventure
videogame. While documenting the game’s pristine environments, they
pushed past the limits of the map, stumbling into an automatically generated
space players aren’t meant to access.
In The Grannies, a multi-channel video artwork inside the gallery, we view
their adventures through an increasingly broken, abstract digital landscape.
Accompanying this installation is Ian MacLarty’s original experimental
videogame Red Desert Render, which recreates the curiosity and community
that the players felt during their time together.
Out of Bounds reveals the materiality of the digital spaces we inhabit,
offering a rare glimpse into the cracks through the eyes of artists

start.title: Ben Drowned

video_links.name: Ben Drowned - The Full Story & ARG

start.brief_description: Ben Drowned is a web serial created by Alexander D. “Jadusable” Hall. in 2010. Originally presented as a series of real events, the narrative describes Jadusable purchasing a cartridge of Legend of Zelda: Majora’s Mask (2000) only to discover it is haunted by a malevolent spirit.

end.title: Inscryption
end.brief_description: Inscryption is an inky black card-based odyssey that blends the deckbuilding roguelike, escape-room style puzzles, and psychological horror into a blood-laced smoothie. Darker still are the secrets inscrybed upon the cards…

constellations_other.name: The radical power of the glitch
constellations_other.description: Brian Eno said, “Whatever you now find weird, ugly, uncomfortable and nasty about a new medium will surely become its signature.” Videogame glitches can seem annoying or obstructive – but for the artists in Out of Bounds, they offer radical creative potential.

links.description: Commercial videogames sometimes use glitch aesthetics for narrative purposes. Inspired by posts like Ben Drowned, Inscryption (2021) sets the player up to expect a straightforward card game – expectations which are subverted through purposeful “glitches” that reveal a larger, darker story.

end.title: Jpegs
end.brief_description: In his series Jpegs (2004), photographer Thomas Ruff printed downloaded images at massive scale, allowing the blown out pixels to distort and warp the original images. This series calls attention to the materiality of the digital artefacts we create, consume and share everyday.

constellations_other.name: The radical power of the glitch
constellations_other.description: Brian Eno said, “Whatever you now find weird, ugly, uncomfortable and nasty about a new medium will surely become its signature.” Videogame glitches can seem annoying or obstructive – but for the artists in Out of Bounds, they offer radical creative potential.

links.description: Other artists use glitch to explore the limits of their practice. In photographer Thomas Ruff’s series Jpegs (2004), he prints compressed files at huge scale, distorting the images beyond recognition. This draws attention to the materiality of the digital images we view and share every day.

end.title: Glitch Feminism
end.brief_description: Legacy Russell’s Glitch Feminism (2020) reclaims the socio-cultural dimensions of the glitch, considering it as an tool for artistic emancipation in a digital culture that consumes our images voraciously.

recommendations.quote: Legacy Russell's Glitch Feminism (2020) reclaims the socio-cultural dimensions of the glitch, considering it as an tool for artistic emancipation in a digital culture where our images are voraciously consumed.

links.description: Like Thomas Ruff, curator Legacy Russell is interested in the materiality that glitches reveal in digital artefacts - and in their subversive power. In her manifesto Glitch Feminism (2020), Russell considers the emancipatory power of the glitch in a digital culture driven by a voracious appetite for our images.

links.description: Glitches take on a mythological dimension. In 2010, Reddit user Jadusable created Ben Drowned, a series of posts in which he described buying a haunted second-hand cartridge of Legend of Zelda: Majora’s Mask (2000). The malevolent ghost reveals himself through scary glitches.
